"Ukrainian women may not be so easy to spot in society, because most of them are in brothels." told Swedish journalist Elaf Ali on the main Swedish channel SVT. It is extremely unacceptable to spread racist stereotypes about Ukrainian women or any other group. To generalize and stigmatize people in this way is reprehensible and goes against basic principles of human dignity and respect. Journalists have a responsibility to report objectively and with empathy, and spreading such prejudicial claims is completely unacceptable. In the past two years, I have personally supported thousands of Ukrainian women and their families, many of whom came to Sweden with their children and elderly relatives. It is important to point out that many Ukrainian men, including husbands and boyfriends, are remaining in Ukraine to protect their country from an invasion, rather than flee to other countries first, as some people from other countries have done. Their narratives serve as a poignant reminder of the bravery and resilience essential for navigating challenges and striving towards a brighter tomorrow. Furthermore, being subject to suspicion and surveillance based on appearance or ethnic origin is deeply unpleasant and offensive. No one should be afraid or suspect just because of their background or appearance. It is high time to take responsibility for your actions and words, and measures are required to counter racism and promote respect, understanding and equality in society. Ayahs were Indian women who were hired by the wealthy British families to care for their children. By the late 19th century Ayahs were the backbone of British families in colonial India. The British mistresses depended heavily on Indian maids in bringing up their children. But their attitudes towards Ayahs (and Indian servants) were very unkind. Thousands of Ayahs from India and other parts of Asia were brought to London to look after young children. They were made to look after and entertain their children during long sea journeys. Many of them were eventually abandoned without any pay or arrangements for their way back home. These women often took to advertisements in local newspapers, asking for help to travel back home. Soon The Ayahs‚Äô Home was established to house, feed, clothe, and protect Ayahs in England. The British children became more familiar with Indian languages and culture because of the close relationship they shared with their Ayah. This broke racial boundaries because Ayahs were raising white children. Ayahs had a lasting impact on the British generations. Impacts that were undesirable to the British, as Victorians believed children were being ‚Äúculturally contaminated‚Äù by a ‚Äúweaker race‚Äù. However, this did not cease the employment of Ayahs, their expertise with children was undeniably excellent. In many parts of the world, including South Asia, the term "Ayah" continued to be used to refer to female caregivers or nursemaids.
